body: Based on https://github.com/golang/go/issues/38485 & https://github.com/golang/go/issues/39782, needs to be revisited once Go 1.16 has been released.

Blocks on release of Golang 1.16 with M1 ARM64 support (see https://blog.golang.org/11years).

Testing on M1 is pending on Github release of MacOSX M1 runners.

Testing could also be done on M1 devices at Mac Stadium. I believe this is what the Go developers are planning.

[https://www.macstadium.com/m1-mini](https://www.macstadium.com/m1-mini)

We will have trouble building a release if we haven't got macOS M1 runners as we build natively on macOS. A cross compiled build is possible but it wouldn't have `rclone mount` support.

Also in the mean time here is how to run rclone on M1 in emulation: https://twitter.com/docomrade/status/1329461082751111168

> just wanted to let you know rclone works fine on the new apple M1 chip using rosetta 2. I did have to download using the direct link because it looks for an ARM Mac version. Also, to get mount/cmount to work I had to install the dev preview of FUSE (apple silicon support).
> and to install FUSE I had to restart my Mac and put it into less secure mode to get the extension for FUSE to work (which is annoying but I'll look into that later and reach out to the macfuse maintainers.). Thanks for making an awesome tool!

Ok it looks like Go is [working](https://github.com/golang/go/issues/38485#issuecomment-730247329) on their master branch. Any pointers on where I can take Rclone from here? I have an Intel Mac as well as Mac Mini M1. So I have Go ready-to-go on Apple Silicon.

@adam-lee wrote:
> Any pointers on where I can take Rclone from here? I have an Intel Mac as well as Mac Mini M1. So I have Go ready-to-go on Apple Silicon.

If you could try [to build rclone](https://rclone.org/install/#install-from-source) using the new Go support, that would be the first step.

I suspect you are going to find that quite a few of the support libraries don't build - finding out which would be a great first step and creating issues on their repos to track linked to this one.

@ncw I believe I am on the HEAD for both Go and Rclone. On my Mac Mini M1, here is the output from the build:

```➜  rclone git:(master) go version
go version devel +3b2a578166 Sat Dec 5 16:20:01 2020 +0000 darwin/arm64
➜  rclone git:(master) go build                                     
➜  rclone git:(master) ./rclone version
rclone v1.54.0-DEV
- os/arch: darwin/arm64
- go version: devel +3b2a578166 Sat Dec 5 16:20:01 2020 +0000
```

Is there a suite of unit tests for Rclone?

Looks like a good start :-)

If you could run `make quicktest` that does quick test of everything.

... if you install OSXFUSE then you can do `GOTAGS=cmount make quicktest` also to test the mount.

and `make racequicktest` would probably be a good idea too.

I would love to see instructions for doing all of this. Or if you could
post a copy of the binaries.

Here it is:

- [quicktest.log](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/files/5649397/quicktest.log)
- [racequicktest.log](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/files/5649557/racequicktest.log)

I see that most of the backend test returned `ok,` but a bunch of common commands like `ls` and `copy` returned `?` with `no test files`. I still took a chance and tried those. And I'm happy that they (appear to) work just fine =).

```
rclone --checksum  --bwlimit=8M --drive-chunk-size=64M --backup-dir=gcrypt:backup  copy /Volumes/backup gcrypt:encrypted --checkers=10 --transfers=10 --tpslimit=10

rclone --checksum  --bwlimit=8M --drive-chunk-size=64M  ls gdrive-id:/Events 
```

What does `no test files` mean? I don't think these commands necessarily failed the tests. Perhaps I need to provide test files?

Let me see if I can also try mounting with FUSE.

> I would love to see instructions for doing all of this. Or if you could post a copy of the binaries.
> […](#)
> On Sun, Dec 6, 2020 at 7:55 AM Adam Lee ***@***.***> wrote: @ncw <https://github.com/ncw> I believe I am on the HEAD for both Go and Rclone. On my Mac Mini M1, here is the output from the build: go version devel +3b2a578166 Sat Dec 5 16:20:01 2020 +0000 darwin/arm64 ➜ rclone git:(master) go build ➜ rclone git:(master) ./rclone version rclone v1.54.0-DEV - os/arch: darwin/arm64 - go version: devel +3b2a578166 Sat Dec 5 16:20:01 2020 +0000 Is there a suite of unit tests for Rclone? — You are receiving this because you authored the thread. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <[#4786 (comment)](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/4786#issuecomment-739506097)>, or unsubscribe <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAAELGDSYU7U6R6X5FK2J4LSTOEMDANCNFSM4T3YWQOQ> .

I had to cross-compile Go [from an Intel Mac](https://github.com/golang/go/issues/38485#issuecomment-730247329). 

From your Intel Mac, compile Golang:
```
Intel-Mac $ git clone https://go.googlesource.com/go goroot
Intel-Mac $ GOARCH=arm64 GOOS=darwin ./bootstrap.bash
```

And then install the generated tarball on your M1, and make sure to sign them:

```
M1-Mac $ codesign -s - /opt/go/bin/*
M1-Mac $ codesign -s - /opt/go/pkg/tool/darwin_arm64/*
M1-Mac $ go version
go version devel +3b2a578166 Sat Dec 5 16:20:01 2020 +0000 darwin/arm64
```

From here, it's matter of compiling `rclone` as per the [wiki](https://rclone.org/install/#install-from-source):

```
M1-Mac $ go get github.com/rclone/rclone@master 
M1-Mac $ go build  
M1-Mac $ file rclone
rclone: Mach-O 64-bit executable arm64
```

@ncw should this command be failing?

```
make tarball
git archive -9 --format=tar.gz --prefix=rclone-v1.54.0-beta.4958.1efb8ea28/ -o build/rclone-v1.54.0-beta.4958.1efb8ea28.tar.gz v1.54.0-beta.4958.1efb8ea28
fatal: could not create archive file 'build/rclone-v1.54.0-beta.4958.1efb8ea28.tar.gz': No such file or directory
make: *** [tarball] Error 128
```

Also, how do I check for dependencies? `Brew` shows all `Rclone` needs is `go`:

```
$ brew info rclone
rclone: stable 1.53.3, HEAD
Rsync for cloud storage
https://rclone.org/
Not installed
From: https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/blob/HEAD/Formula/rclone.rb
License: MIT
==> Dependencies
Build: go ✘
```

Just got rclone running natively on my M1 MBA, but `rclone mount dropbox:/ ~/db` gives me the following error:

```
2020/12/07 00:35:38 NOTICE: macOS users: please try "rclone cmount" as it will be the default in v1.54
2020/12/07 00:35:38 Fatal error: failed to mount FUSE fs: cannot locate OSXFUSE
```

My copy of rclone was installed via `go get github.com/rclone/rclone`, and `rclone version` gives

```
rclone v1.53.3-DEV
- os/arch: darwin/arm64
- go version: devel +7716a2fbb7 Sun Nov 22 11:44:49 2020 -0500
```

I have installed [macFUSE 4.0.4](https://osxfuse.github.io/2020/11/30/macFUSE-4.0.4.html), which is arm64-native. Also, SSHFS runs fine on my machine.

Does anyone know how to tell rclone where to find macFUSE or OSXFUSE?

### Solution

Use `rclone cmount`. If `unknown command "cmount" for "rclone"`, recompile rclone via

```
git clone https://github.com/rclone/rclone.git
cd rclone
go build -tags cmount
```

Thanks @darthShadow and @ncw.

> should this command be failing?

Try creating a `build` subdirectory in the rclone folder and running the command again after that.

> how do I check for dependencies?

There are no external dependencies required other than go for building rclone.

> should this command be failing?
> 
> ```
> make tarball
> git archive -9 --format=tar.gz --prefix=rclone-v1.54.0-beta.4958.1efb8ea28/ -o build/rclone-v1.54.0-beta.4958.1efb8ea28.tar.gz v1.54.0-beta.4958.1efb8ea28
> fatal: could not create archive file 'build/rclone-v1.54.0-beta.4958.1efb8ea28.tar.gz': No such file or directory
> make: *** [tarball] Error 128
> ```

Normally you run that after you've made a release so have a `build` directory. I wouldn't have thought you'd need to run it though as all it does is package the source into a .tar.gz and you've got the source in a git repo already.

> Also, how do I check for dependencies? `Brew` shows all `Rclone` needs is `go`:

Go is all you need, unless you want to build with cmount support in which case you'll need the OSXFUSE headers too. To build with `cmount` support you'll need to build with the tag `-tags cmount`.
